title: Pan-Seared Ribeye Steak with Herb Butter
description: Restaurant-quality ribeye steak showcasing advanced techniques: searing, basting, resting, and compound butter preparation.

steps.instruction_text: Remove steaks from refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking to bring to room temperature.
Score the fat cap of the steaks in a crosshatch pattern using a sharp knife, being careful not to cut into the meat.
Pat the steaks completely dry with paper towels and season generously with coarse salt and freshly cracked black pepper on all sides.
For the herb butter: Mince fresh rosemary, thyme, and garlic finely.
In a bowl, cream the softened butter with the minced herbs, garlic, salt, and lemon zest until well combined.
Shape the herb butter into a log using plastic wrap, then refrigerate until firm.
Heat a cast-iron skillet over high heat until smoking hot, about 5 minutes.
Add a thin layer of oil to the pan and sear the steaks for 3-4 minutes on the first side without moving them, until a deep golden-brown crust forms.
Flip the steaks and sear the second side for another 3-4 minutes.
Reduce heat to medium and add butter, crushed garlic, and fresh thyme sprigs to the pan.
Tilt the pan and continuously baste the steaks with the foaming butter for 2-3 minutes, spooning it over the top.
For medium-rare, cook until internal temperature reaches 130°F (54°C) when checked with a meat thermometer.
Transfer steaks to a cutting board and let rest for 5-7 minutes to allow juices to redistribute.
While resting, slice the herb butter into rounds.
Slice the steak against the grain at a 45-degree angle into thick strips.
Plate the sliced steak, drizzle with any resting juices, and top with a round of herb butter.
Garnish with flaky sea salt and fresh herbs before serving immediately.
